robowars
Class Robot

java.lang.Object
  robowars.Robot
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Runnable
public class Robot
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable

The Robot class serves as the base class for any user defined Robot. The methods provided by this and other classes assume the following conventions:

  • The origin is located at the top left corner of the battle window
  • Increasing x is towards the right side, increasing y is towards the bottom of the window
  • All angles are measured in radians with respect to positive x axis in the clockwise direction
  • All angles returned are in the range [0-2PI)
  • The orientation of a robot is the direction the robot is facing

Method Detail

setVelocity

public final void setVelocity(double vel)
sets the magnitude of linear velocity (in units/game time) of the robot to vel. Subsequently the robot moves at the specified rate. Velocity of the robot cannot exceed Constants.MAXVEL.

Parameters:
vel - - the linear velocity to be set to.

setAngularVelocity

public final void setAngularVelocity(double angVel)
sets the magnitude of the angular velocity (in radians/game time) of the robot to angVel. Subsequently, the robot rotates at that rate. Angular velocity cannot exceed Constants.MAX_ANGVEL

Parameters:
angVel - - the angular velocity to be set to.

toString

public final java.lang.String toString()
returns the name of the robot.

Returns:
name of the robot.

ahead

public final void ahead(double distance)
sets the linear distance to be moved by the robot. The method returns immediately and does not wait for the movement to complete. For example, calling ahead(10) and turn(Math.PI) consecutively causes the robot to move in a curved path. Calling ahead overrides the distance to be moved set by an earlier call to it. Note that acceleration is assumed to be infinity.

Parameters:
distance - - distance by which to move. Negative distance move the robot backwards.

turn

public final void turn(double angle)
sets the angular distance to be moved by the robot. The method returns immediately and does not wait for the movement to complete. For example, calling turn(Math.PI) and ahead(10) consecutively causes the robot to move in a curved path. Calling turn overrides the angular distance to be moved set by an earlier call to it. Note that angular acceleration is assumed to be infinity.

Parameters:
angle - - angle by which to move. Negative angle rotates the robot in the anti-clockwise direction.

returns the x coordinate of the robot's center.

x coordinate

returns the y coordinate of the robot's center.

run

public final void run()
Specified by:
run in interface java.lang.Runnable

execute

public void execute()
this is the main method to be overriden by the user in his class. The method should contain code that drives the robot

update

public final void update()
the method update should be periodically called by the robot. If this method is not called frequently enough, the robot will stall. The robot comes out of the stalled state only if the update method is called a sufficient number of times subsequently. Calls to turn, gunTurn, ahead while the robot is in the stalled state will affect the robot's motion on resuming in the normal way. Note that the velocity and angular velocity is not set to zero when the robot is in the stalled state.

getName

public final java.lang.String getName()
returns the name of the robot.

Returns:
name of the robot

this method is called when the robot wins a round.

onDeath

public void onDeath(DeathEvent de)
this method is called when the robot dies.

fire

public final Bullet fire(double power)
Fire a bullet of the specified power. The bullet's power determines its velocity, the gun heat generated and the damage caused to an opponent. The health of the robot reduces by the power of the bullet on firing. The robots health increases by twice the power of the bullet if the bullet hits an opponent.

Parameters:
power - - power of the bullet fired
Returns:
bullet that is fired
See Also:
Constants

getTime

public final long getTime()
returns the game time. The game time is set to 0 at the beginning of each round. Quantities such as linear and angular velocity of the robot and the angular velocity of the gun are defined with respect to game time

Returns:
game time

onBulletHit

public void onBulletHit(BulletHitEvent event)
This event is generated when this robot's bullet hits an opponent

onBulletMissed

public void onBulletMissed(BulletMissedEvent event)
This event is generated when this robots's bullet hits a wall

onHitByBullet

public void onHitByBullet(HitByBulletEvent event)
This event is generated when the robot is hit by a bullet

onHitRobot

public void onHitRobot(HitRobotEvent event)
This event is generated when the robot collides with another robot. The robots linear velocity and angular velocity are set to zero subsequently. Also the linear and angular distance to move set by the robot in previous calls to turn and ahead is reset to zero.

onHitWall

public void onHitWall(HitWallEvent event)
This event is generated when the robot hits a wall. The robots linear and angular velocity are set to zero subsequently. Also the linear and angular distance to move set by the robot in previous calls to turn and ahead is reset to zero.

getMap

public final char[][] getMap()
returns the map of the battle. The battle field is assumed to be divided into cells as defined in the map. A 1 indicates presence of a wall at that cell. A zero indicates absence of the wall at that cell. The first dimension of the array returned corresponds to the y direction and the second direction corresponds to the x direction

Returns:
map of the battle field

getVisibleRobots

public final java.util.ArrayList getVisibleRobots()
returns an ArrayList of visible robots. Visibility is defined as follows: If any part of another robot is visible from the center of this robot, then that robot is considered to be visible. Robots may only be unoccluded by walls present in the map.

Returns:
list of visible robots

turnGun

public final void turnGun(double radians)
sets the angular distance to be moved by the robot's gun. The method returns immediately and does not wait for the movement to complete. Calling turnGun overrides the gun's angular distance to be moved set by an earlier call to it. The angular acceleration of the gun is assumed to be infinity.

Parameters:
radians - - angle by which to move. Negative angle rotates the gun in the anti-clockwise direction.
See Also:
Constants
